title: About
text: About this site

title: Recipe Art
text:
I had some fun making some recipe art as part of this project.
Each fruit has a fun picture and some eclectic recipes suggestions in alphabetic order.

title: Cookbook
text:
Welcome to my flavorful corner of the internet! As someone who delights in experimenting with new recipes, I’ve found that generative AI brings a novel twist to the kitchen. By providing innovative and unique combinations, it keeps my culinary journey fresh. This website serves as both a repository for the dishes I’ve tried and a space for me to reflect on what worked and what did not.
Inspired by the delectable artistry of Yotam Ottolenghi, I often challenge the generative AI to reimagine his recipes with alternative ingredients, ensuring that my pantry’s constraints never dull my taste buds. I invite you to explore this collection of recipes, and perhaps discover your own flavorful inspiration along the way.

title: Cookbook
text: Recipes

title: Gammon and Vegetable Stew with Mint
text:
Prepared for Instagram in January in Westbrook.






Prompt: “A humorous painting of a laptop inside a cooking pot, wearing a chefs hat, still life in the style of Paul Cézanne”

title: Porter Beer-Braised Beef with Ottolenghi-inspired Roast Potatoes
text:
Recipe for Mother’s day, May 14, 2023.






Prompt: “Capture the essence of Gustave Caillebotte’s style in a still life painting, showcasing a platter of porter beer-braised beef, a dish of Ottolenghi-inspired roast potatoes, and a bowl of fresh broccoli, peas, and mixed greens salad with pomegranate arils”

title: Porter Beer-Braised Beef with Ottolenghi-inspired Roast Potatoes
section: Main Course: Porter Beer-Braised Beef with Ottolenghi-inspired Roast Potatoes
text:
Main Course: Porter Beer-Braised Beef with Ottolenghi-inspired Roast Potatoes
Ingredients:

1.5kg beef roast (such as topside or rib-eye)
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
3 tbsp olive oil
1.2kg small waxy potatoes, peeled and halved
2 tbsp za’atar
1 tbsp sumac
Zest of 1 lemon
3 tbsp chopped fresh parsley
2 bottles (24 oz) porter beer
3 celery stalks, chopped
2 onions, chopped
3 carrots, chopped

For the gravy:

Drippings from the beef
2 tbsp all-purpose flour
1 cup beef broth
Salt and pepper to taste

Instructions:

Season the beef roast generously with salt and pepper. Heat 2 tbsp of olive oil in a large pot over medium-high heat. Sear the beef on all sides until browned, about 3-4 minutes per side.
Add the porter beer to the pot, followed by the chopped celery, onions, and carrots. The beer should cover the beef roast. Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and cover the pot. Let it simmer for 2.5 to 3 hours, or until the beef is fork-tender.
Preheat the oven to 200°C (400°F).
Prepare the roast potatoes. In a large bowl, toss the potatoes with the remaining 1 tbsp of olive oil, za’atar, sumac, and a pinch of salt and pepper. Spread the potatoes in a single layer on a baking sheet and roast for 35-40 minutes, or until golden and crispy, turning them halfway through cooking.
Remove the beef from the pot and place it on a cutting board. Tent with foil, and let it rest for 15-20 minutes.
While the beef is resting, prepare the gravy. Strain the cooking liquid from the pot into a bowl, reserving the vegetables. Skim off any fat from the surface of the liquid.
In the same pot, heat 2 tbsp of the beef drippings over medium heat. Whisk in the flour and cook, stirring constantly, for 1-2 minutes. Slowly whisk in the reserved cooking liquid and beef broth. Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat and simmer until the gravy has thickened, about 5-10 minutes. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
To serve, slice the beef roast and arrange on a platter with the roasted potatoes and reserved vegetables. Sprinkle the potatoes with lemon zest and chopped parsley. Serve the gravy alongside the beef.

title: Porter Beer-Braised Beef with Ottolenghi-inspired Roast Potatoes
section: Broccoli, Peas, and Mixed Greens Salad with Pomegranate Arils
text:
Broccoli, Peas, and Mixed Greens Salad with Pomegranate Arils
Ingredients:

1 large head of broccoli, cut into small florets
1 cup frozen peas, thawed
4 cups mixed greens (such as spinach, arugula, and baby kale)
1 cup pomegranate arils
1/4 cup crumbled feta cheese (optional)

For the dressing:

3 tbsp extra-virgin olive oil
2 tbsp freshly squeezed lemon juice
1 tbsp honey
1 small garlic clove, minced
Salt and freshly ground black pepper, to taste

Instructions:

Microwave the peas in a bowl of water, up to the level of covering the peas, for 8-12 minutes. Drain water and let cool.
Bring a pot of salted water to a boil. Add the broccoli florets and cook for 2-3 minutes, or until they’re bright green and slightly tender. Drain the broccoli and immediately transfer it to a bowl of ice water to stop the cooking process. Let the broccoli sit in the ice water for a minute and then drain.
In a large salad bowl, combine the blanched broccoli, cooked peas, mixed greens, and pomegranate arils. If desired, add crumbled feta cheese for extra flavor and texture.
Prepare the dressing by whisking together the extra-virgin olive oil, lemon juice, honey, minced garlic, salt, and pepper in a small bowl.
Drizzle the dressing over the salad and toss to combine. Serve the salad alongside the porter beer-braised beef and Ottolenghi-inspired roast potatoes. Enjoy!

title: Roasted Cauliflower and Chickpea Salad
text:
Prepared for a soirée on the 14th of April in Paris.






Prompt: “Paint a beautiful Gustave Caillebotte-inspired kitchen scene_ a bowl brimming with golden roasted cauliflower and chickpeas, bathed in creamy tahini”

title: Roasted Cauliflower and Chickpea Salad
text:
Ingredients

2 heads cauliflower, cut into small florets
2 cans chickpeas, drained and rinsed
2 tsp ground cumin
2 tsp ground coriander
1 tsp smoked paprika
1/2 tsp cayenne pepper
6 tbsp olive oil
Salt and pepper
1/2 cup tahini
4 tbsp lemon juice
2 garlic cloves, minced
1/2 cup water
Mixed greens, for serving

title: Roasted Cauliflower and Chickpea Salad
text:
Instructions

Preheat the oven to 400°F (200°C).
In a large bowl, toss the cauliflower florets and chickpeas with cumin, coriander, smoked paprika, cayenne pepper, 4 tablespoons of olive oil, salt, and pepper until evenly coated.
Spread the cauliflower and chickpeas on two baking sheets lined with parchment paper and roast for 25 to 30 minutes or until golden and tender.
While the cauliflower and chickpeas are roasting, whisk together the tahini, lemon juice, garlic, remaining 2 tablespoons of olive oil, water, and salt in a small bowl until smooth.
Once the cauliflower and chickpeas are done roasting, let them cool for a few minutes.
In a large bowl, toss the roasted cauliflower and chickpeas with the tahini dressing until evenly coated.
Serve the salad on a bed of mixed greens.

Enjoy your Roasted Cauliflower and Chickpea Salad!

title: Salmon with Green Pea Sauce and Charred Broccoli
text:
Prepared for a dinner party on the 26th of April 2023 in Lund.






Prompt: “Paint a beautiful Gustave Caillebotte-inspired dining scene_ glistening salmon fillets with golden skin, accompanied by vibrant green pea sauce”

title: Salmon with Green Pea Sauce and Charred Broccoli
section: Starter: Salmon with Green Pea Sauce and Charred Broccoli
text:
Starter: Salmon with Green Pea Sauce and Charred Broccoli
Ingredients: - 6 salmon fillets (about 150g each, skin on)

400g frozen green peas, thawed
handful of mint, washed
200ml heavy cream
1 small garlic clove, crushed
Zest and juice of 1 lemon
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
500g broccoli, cut into florets
2 tbsp olive oil
1 tbsp chopped fresh dill for garnish

Instructions: 1. Preheat the oven to 180°C (350°F).

Season the salmon fillets with salt and pepper. Place them on a baking tray, skin side down, and roast for 12-15 minutes, or until cooked to your desired level.
In the meantime, prepare the green pea sauce. In a blender, combine the peas, heavy cream, garlic, lemon zest, and juice. Blend until smooth, then season with salt and pepper to taste. If the sauce is too thick, add a splash of water to thin it out.
In a large bowl, toss the broccoli florets with olive oil, salt, and pepper. Heat a large grill pan or skillet over medium-high heat. Cook the broccoli, turning occasionally, until charred and tender, about 5-7 minutes.
To serve, spoon some green pea sauce onto each plate, top with a salmon fillet, and arrange the charred broccoli alongside. Garnish with fresh dill.

title: Salmon with Green Pea Sauce and Charred Broccoli
section: Main Course: Beef Roast with Ottolenghi-inspired Roast Potatoes
text:
Main Course: Beef Roast with Ottolenghi-inspired Roast Potatoes
Ingredients: - 1.5kg beef roast (such as topside or rib-eye)

Salt and freshly ground black pepper
3 tbsp olive oil
1.2kg small waxy potatoes, peeled and halved
2 tbsp za’atar
1 tbsp sumac
Zest of 1 lemon
3 tbsp chopped fresh parsley

Instructions: 1. Preheat the oven to 200°C (400°F).

Season the beef roast generously with salt and pepper. Heat 2 tbsp of olive oil in a large ovenproof skillet or roasting pan over medium-high heat. Sear the beef on all sides until browned, about 3-4 minutes per side.
Transfer the skillet or roasting pan to the oven and roast the beef for 50-60 minutes, or until a meat thermometer inserted into the thickest part of the roast reads 52°C (125°F) for medium-rare. Adjust the cooking time if you prefer your beef more well-done.
Remove the beef from the oven, tent with foil, and let it rest for 15-20 minutes.
While the beef is resting, prepare the roast potatoes. In a large bowl, toss the potatoes with the remaining 1 tbsp of olive oil, za’atar, sumac, and a pinch of salt and pepper. Spread the potatoes in a single layer on a baking sheet and roast for 35-40 minutes, or until golden and crispy, turning them halfway through cooking.
To serve, slice the beef roast and arrange on a platter with the roasted potatoes. Sprinkle the potatoes with lemon zest and chopped parsley.

title: Chicken and parmesan soup with pappardelle
text:
Recipe for a sick Kathy, based on this recipe.






Prompt: “Using the contrast and realism found in Johannes Vermeer’s paintings, create a vibrant still life image, showcasing the ‘Chicken and Parmesan Soup with Pappardelle’. Illuminate the scene with warm, soft light akin to Vermeer’s ‘The Milkmaid’, emphasizing the rich texture of the soup, the steam rising from the bowl”

title: Chicken and parmesan soup with pappardelle
text:
Info
Prep 20 min Cook 1 hr 10 min Serves 4

title: Chicken and parmesan soup with pappardelle
text:
Ingredients

1.4 kg of chicken pieces (such as thighs or breasts)
1 whole head garlic, halved, plus 4 cloves, peeled and crushed
1 onion, cut into 4 wedges
Salt and black pepper
2 tbsp olive oil
2 carrots, peeled and cut into roughly 15mm cubes (220g net weight)
3 sticks celery, cut at an angle into roughly 1cm-thick slices (200g net weight)
3 bay leaves
1½ tbsp thyme leaves, finely chopped
60g parmesan, finely grated, plus 1 small piece of rind
5 plum tomatoes, coarsely grated and skins discarded (320g)
2 tsp tomato paste
180g dried pappardelle nests
15g basil leaves, finely shredded
1 red chilli, deseeded and finely chopped
500ml beer of your choice
1.5 litres of water (or chicken stock if you prefer)

title: Chicken and parmesan soup with pappardelle
text:
Instructions

Season chicken pieces with salt and black pepper.
Put the olive oil in a large pan and set over medium-high heat. Add chicken pieces to the pan and saute until browned on all sides. Remove the chicken pieces and set aside.
In the same pan, saute the garlic, onion, carrots and celery for about 4 minutes until they start to soften.
Return the chicken pieces to the pan, add the bay leaves, thyme, parmesan rind, the beer, water (or chicken stock), and bring to a simmer. Cover and cook for 40-50 minutes, or until the chicken is cooked through.
Remove the chicken pieces and once cool enough to handle, shred the meat; discard the skin and bones.
Add the crushed garlic, tomatoes, and tomato paste to the pan. Cook for three minutes, until the tomatoes cook down slightly. If using water, add 1.5 litres of hot water, salt, and a generous grind of pepper. Bring to a boil, then lower the heat to medium and cook for 15 minutes, or until the vegetables have softened.
Ladle out 400g of the soup, about 50/50 liquid to solids (avoid the bay and rind), transfer to a blender and blitz smooth. Stir back into the soup pan and turn up the heat to medium-high.
Add the pasta, shredded chicken and a good grind of pepper, and cook for 15 minutes, or until the pasta is al dente. Discard the bay leaves and parmesan rind.
Divide the soup between four bowls, top with the basil, chilli, a good grind of pepper and a sprinkling of grated parmesan, and serve with extra parmesan alongside.

This should give you a similar flavor profile to the original recipe, but with a hint of beer flavor from the added beer in the cooking process.
